docs.lead_paragraph: Following is the second set of answers from Joel Kotkin, co-author of "Reviving the City of Aspiration," a study of the challenges facing the city's middle class for the Center for an Urban Future. This week, he is answering readers' questions about the importance of the city's upwardly mobile class and what can be done to revive this troubled population.

headline.main: Answers About New York's Middle Class, Part 2

docs.abstract: Taking Questions: Joel Kotkin, co-author of "Reviving the City of Aspiration," a study of the challenges facing the city's middle class for the Center for an Urban Future, answers readers' questions.
docs.snippet: Taking Questions: Joel Kotkin, co-author of "Reviving the City of Aspiration," a study of the challenges facing the city's middle class for the Center for an Urban Future, answers readers' questions.

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had once hoped that a bit of Citigroup's $400 million endorsement pact with the Mets might trickle down their way, through a naming rights deal of their own for the station. But those hopes evaporated with the bank's near collapse and the Mets' refusal to share the wealth.

headline.main: Citi Field? Not for the Subway Station

docs.abstract: Spurred by rising public anger, federal and state investigators are preparing for a surge of prosecutions of financial fraud, The New York Times's David Segal reports. Across the country, attorneys general have already begun indicting dozens of loan processors, mortgage brokers and bank officers. docs.lead_paragraph: When the economy began tumbling last fall, I immediately thought of Jill Swenson.

headline.main: Amid Hard Times, A View From Off the Grid

docs.abstract: When the economy began tumbling last fall, I immediately thought of Jill Swenson, a former college professor who quit her job in academia to become a full-time organic farmer and self-sufficient producer of power.
docs.snippet: When the economy began tumbling last fall, I immediately thought of Jill Swenson, a former college professor who quit her job in academia to become a full-time organic farmer and self-sufficient producer of power.

docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday at Balkinization, Andrew Koppelman published a lengthy post on the issue of whether Barack Obama is a socialist, the charge that many are now hurling at him. Via a long historical review of left political responses to capitalism, Koppelman argues that "Obama properly belongs in a specific anti-socialist movement on the left, Social Democracy, which accepts a capitalist economy but demands a strong state to moderate its failures and excesses."

headline.main: Obama is a Social Democrat, Not a Socialist

docs.abstract: President Obama isn't a socialist, but an anti-socialist of the Left.
docs.snippet: President Obama isn't a socialist, but an anti-socialist of the Left.

headline.main: Hold On! What’s Wrong With a Little More Égalité?
